pr_title: Spark: Implement an adapter to wrap Row into DataFile

timeline.message: Spark: Implement an adapter to wrap Row into DataFile

timeline.bodyText: As much as I don't like to use the index, referring by column name seems to incur an additional penalty as we will resolve the column name every time (based on what I see in Spark Row).
timeline.author: aokolnychyi

replies.bodyText: If we assume that the type passed in here matches the Row, then we should be able to derive the ordinals from that type instead of hard-coding them. I think this would produce an int[] of expected offset to actual offset, like we use in the Avro generics. What do you think?
replies.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText: Otherwise, I think it would probably be worth the performance penalty to ensure correctness.
replies.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText: @rdblue, do you mean passing the Spark type alongside the Iceberg type and building a mapping in the constructor?
replies.author: aokolnychyi

replies.bodyText: Ideally, yes. But if that's not possible we know that the DataFile that will be passed in comes from a metadata table (because we control the implementations that use this) so it would be okay to assume that we know what the Spark schema is.
replies.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText: Okay, I've updated this to handle arbitrary projections.
replies.author: aokolnychyi

timeline.bodyText: I am using getAs instead of getLong as getLong and other methods specific to primitives perform a check if the value is null. The downside might be boxing/unboxing.
timeline.author: aokolnychyi

replies.bodyText: Actually, Spark row uses Array[Any] which I assume allocates an array of Objects. So, Spark stores boxed versions and we have to unbox it anyway. If we used getLong, we would also perform a null check.
replies.author: aokolnychyi

timeline.bodyText: It would be nice to have some Javadoc about this, like that values are converted to Iceberg's internal representation.
timeline.author: rdblue
